bibl.title: Letter from Joseph H. White to Henry Rose Carter, March 21, 1923

div1.p: White agrees with Carter on handling endemic situations. He sends Carter a letter from Avila describing a possible yellow fever case, which he thinks is a false diagnosis.

YELLOW FEVER COUNCIL
HENRY R. CARTER, M.D. HIDEYO NOGUCHI, M.D. JOSEPH H. WHITE, M.D.
Dear Doctor:
div1.p:
I had intended to see you personally before now
but refrained from doing so because Laura told me it would
be a very bad thing for you to be exposed to a Coryza and
I have had a villainous one practically ever since the night
you dined with me.

I want to comment slightly upon your note of Feb-
ruary 14 in regard to handling of endemic situations. I am
now and have been for years in full accord with everything
that you say in that note. I thought I had so expressed my
views to you at your house and am therefore somewhat at a
loss to get the raison d'etre of the note in question. Any-
way this is merely to tell you that there is not now and
never has been any disagreement between us as to the methods
of handling endemic situations.

I shall enclose a paper submitted to Doctor Cuaron
by Doctor Avila which will probably interest you as illustra-
ting the capacity of some men for using their imaginations.

I shall have the pleasure of seeing you as soon
as I can do so without jeopardizing your own health.
div1.closer:
Sincerely your friend, J. H. White Doctor H R Carter
